stages.name: Overwintering adults
stages.status: Adults overwinter in litter under tree
stages.scouting: None
stages.management: No management possible when adults are ovewintering.

stages.name: Active adults/eggs
stages.status: Adults emerge from litter, fly or crawl to tree terminals, feed and begin to lay eggs
stages.scouting: Scout for feeding wounds on leaders, sap dripping. Use Tedders traps to monitor for adults. Place in areas of previous white pine weevil infestation.  Soil temperature at 2 inches of 50F indicates adult emergence.
stages.management: Begin trapping. Apply pesticides within 7 days from first trap catch. Apply pesticide applications when day temperatures reach 50F. Apply pesticide to leader and upper branches only.

stages.name: Eggs/larvae
stages.status: Eggs laid in leaders and branch whorls just below, larvae feed between bark and wood
stages.phenologicalMarkers: Before mockorange or mountain laurel finish blooming
stages.scouting: Scout for feeding wounds on leaders, sap dripping. Use Tedders traps to monitor for adults. Look for drooping leaders
stages.management: Prune out and destroy drooping leaders ('shepherd's crooks'). Cut below bark discoloration.

stages.name: Adult emergence
stages.status: Adults emerge from leaders, feed and shelter in litter under trees
stages.scouting: None
stages.management: No management possible once adults emerge

hosts: All conifers, especially spruce and fir

stages.name: Egg (phase 1)
stages.status: Overwinters as egg under bud scales and at base of needles
stages.scouting: None
stages.management: Manage surrounding area to encourage beneficial insects

stages.name: Egg (phase 2)
stages.status: Overwintering eggs hatch
stages.scouting: Scout older branches before bud break on trees with history of spruce spider mites, particularly on south side of tree, for red roundish eggs
stages.management: Dormant oil spray
stages.biologicalControl: Predator mites, lacewing larvae, lady beeltes, hover fly larvae

stages.name: Nymph/adult (phase 1)
stages.status: Nymphs and adults active, many generations per season
stages.scouting: Scout for small yellow spots on needles on interior lower branches.  May become rusty or bronzed. Evaluate population by tapping branches over light colored surface, dark green when squashed. Webbing with severe infestation. Also scout for beneficial insects.
stages.management: None
stages.biologicalControl: Predator mites, lacewing larvae, lady beeltes, hover fly larvae

stages.name: Nymph/adult (phase 2)
stages.status: Peak activity for nymphs and adults
stages.scouting: Scout for small yellow spots on needles on interior lower branches.  May become rusty or bronzed. Evaluate population by tapping branches over light colored surface, dark green when squashed. Webbing with severe infestation. Also scout for beneficial insects.
stages.management: Pesticide application if necessary. Threshold is 10 mites per branch tap. Pesticide application may affect beneficial insects and mites.
stages.biologicalControl: Predator mites, lacewing larvae, lady beeltes, hover fly larvae

stages.name: Nymph/adult (phase 3)
stages.status: Nymphs and adults less active
stages.scouting: Scout for small yellow spots on needles on interior lower branches.  May become rusty or bronzed. Evaluate population by tapping branches over light colored surface, dark green when squashed. Webbing with severe infestation. Also scout for beneficial insects.
stages.management: No pesticide applications as populations decline at temperatures above 80-90 F

stages.name: Nymph/adult (phase 4)
stages.status: Peak activity for nymphs and adults
stages.phenologicalMarkers: Witch hazel, sweet autumn clematis blooming, Arrowood viburnum fruit in color
stages.scouting: Scout for small yellow spots on needles on interior lower branches.  May become rusty or bronzed. Evaluate population by tapping branches over light colored surface, dark green when squashed. Webbing with severe infestation. Also scout for beneficial insects.
stages.management: Pesticide application if necessary. Threshold is 10 mites per branch tap. Pesticide application may affect beneficial insects and mites.
stages.biologicalControl: Predator mites, lacewing larvae, lady beeltes, hover fly larvae

stages.name: Adult/egg
stages.status: Overwintering eggs laid
stages.scouting: Mark trees for scouting in spring.
stages.management: None

stages.name: Eggs
stages.status: Overwinters as egg
stages.scouting: Scout for overwintering eggs before buds swell
stages.management: Do not apply nitrogen to infested trees before bud break. If severe issues with balsam twig aphid, plant species with later bud break.  Canaan is later than Fraser which is later than balsam, in general

stages.name: Stem mothers/nymphs
stages.status: Overwintering eggs hatch to stem mothers, which produce nymphs
stages.phenologicalMarkers: Buds swelling and just opening. Silver maple, red maple
stages.scouting: Evaluate population by tapping branches over dark colored surface.  Also scout for beneficial insects and mites.
stages.management: Pesticide application if necessary.  Threshold is 3 aphids per tree. Control is most important in last 2 years before harvest, unless damage is excessive prior to that.  Apply pesticide on warm day before budcap loosens.
stages.biologicalControl: Predators include ladybeetle adults and larvae, lacewings, ants, hover fly larvae, syrphid flies and yellow jackets.  Pesticide applications may affect beneficial insects.

stages.name: Nymphs/adults
stages.status: 3-4 generation per year. Nymphs and adults feed on tree but only feeding during needle development causes twisting
stages.scouting: Scout for twisted needles, honeydew (indicated by presence of bees, wasps and ants) and insects to determine trees to treat next year.
stages.management: Pick and destroy young cones where aphids may hide.
stages.biologicalControl: Predators include ladybeetle adults and larvae, lacewings, ants, hover fly larvae, syrphid flies and yellow jackets.  Pesticide applications may affect beneficial insects.

stages.name: Winged adults
stages.status: Lay overwintering eggs
stages.scouting: None
stages.management: If severe issues with balsam twig aphid, plant species with later bud break.  Canaan is later than Fraser which is later than balsam, in general

stages.name: Overwinter as larvae
stages.status: Larvae pupate in the soil beneath infested trees
stages.scouting: Place at least 3 traps per field on the north side of previously infested trees before the daily temperature reaches 60F for several days. Check traps daily and continue until no midges are caught for several days.
stages.management: Plant varieties with later bud break. Remove overgrown trees from the plantation as damage can be more severe on older trees.

stages.name: Adult
stages.status: Adult midges emerge from the soil beneath trees.
stages.scouting: Check traps daily and continue until no midges are caught for several days.
stages.management: Pesticide application is based on collection of adults in traps as chemicals are only effective against adults. The first application should be made as soon as first adults are noted.  A second application may be applied if adults continue to emerge.
stages.biologicalControl: Parasitic chalcid wasps are tiny.  They may be affected by pesticide applications.

stages.name: Larvae
stages.status: Eggs hatch to larvae which bore into, and feed on, needles, causing small swollen galls
stages.scouting: August - Scout for swollen galls on needles.  Needles may yellow and bend at gall. Mark trees for traps in the spring.
stages.management: Remove heavily infested trees before larvae leave the needles in late fall.  Plant varieties with later bud break. Remove overgrown trees from the plantation as damage can be more severe on older trees.

hosts: Fir, sometimes spruce, Douglas fir, pine

stages.name: Adult
stages.status: Overwinter as various stages, including adults
stages.scouting: Scout underside of needles for scale.  Mark trees for later scouting for crawlers. If only a few trees are infested, consider removing them - tarped so scale is not spread.  Yellos sticky cards can be used to trap males to indicate when eggs are being laid.
stages.management: Remove hemlocks near plantation that can act as reservoirs. Space trees at planting to minimize movement from tree to tree. Remove weeds to expose lower branches to allow scouting and coverage with pesticides.  Butt pruning can remove heavily infested lower branches.Limit preseason use of nitrogen fertilizers as they increase survival and rate of development.

stages.name: Adults/egg/crawler
stages.status: Adults produce eggs that hatch to crawlers.
stages.scouting: Scout trees for crawler emergence. No specific thresholds have been determined.
stages.management: Dormant  treatment if necessary.
stages.biologicalControl: Lady beetles, lacewings and parasitic wasps.  Pesticide use may affect beneficial insects.

stages.name: Unknown...
stages.status: Crawlers are produced over a long period.
stages.scouting: Scout trees for crawler emergence. No specific thresholds have been determined.
stages.management: None
stages.biologicalControl: Lady beetles, lacewings and parasitic wasps.

stages.name: Crawler
stages.status: Crawlers are produced over a long period.
stages.phenologicalMarkers: Tatarian honeysuckle, beauty bush, ninebark blooming
stages.scouting: Scout trees for crawler emergence. No specific thresholds have been determined.
stages.management: Pesticide applications if necessary.  Clean equipment between fields to prevent spread and always work from least infested to most infested areas.
stages.biologicalControl: Lady beetles, lacewings and parasitic wasps.  Pesticide use may affect beneficial insects.

stages.name: Adult
stages.status: Ovewintering stages develop.
stages.scouting: Spruce - scout for brown galls to mark trees to scout. Douglas fir - Scout for egg masses under waxy mass on outer growth.
stages.management: Do not fertilize infested trees.
